This product it is not very effective in terms of time. It takes a lot of time to take care of one leg, very long time, and the results are not perfect. But with few procedures, it gets better. I own one, and I am sending one as a gift to my friend, I like it. So far it works well after extensive use of three people in the house for 4-5 months.
  901. Ouch, ouch, double ouch....<br /><br />I have to admit, I was really not prepared for just how painful this thing would be. I'm a shaver/waxer/cream hair removal kinda girl. And it drives me nuts. Because it's an everyday affair that gets tedious, expensive and downright annoying.<br /><br />So when I popped this thing out of the box after it arrived(and I had been dancing on pins and needles for it to get here as part of my New Year's Resolution to be a happier me), I was quick to read the instructions and then plug her in for a test drive. Now, I had been avoiding shaving for a few days to get some good growth, as it was my understanding that these things work better with a slightly longer hair. But I finally gave in and had shaved just a couple days ago during my agonizing wait, as I could no longer handle the bristles on my legs.<br /><br />First contact with skin was indescribable. I've had two c-sections and had babies latch on to my breasts. I thought that hurt. Thought. I was wrong. THIS is pain. This thing literally RIPS the hair out of its happy socket. It drew blood on me several times!!! And I had to stop (because I was doing the wussy dance so much) multiple times and try a different area.<br /><br />Now having said all that, you would think I would hate the thing and ship it back to Amazon faster than a long-tailed cat escapes a room full of rocking chairs.<br /><br />Contraire, mon frere. Actually, I think it's AWESOME. After multiple swipes, the thing actually starts to soften and/or numb the skin. The pain subsides and you are left with virtually hairless, smooth gams, pits, Happy Trail (or chin - which was the biggest reason I bought the thing).<br /><br />And then it became obsessive. Where else on my body did I have unwanted hair? I won't go into details, but I will say that, despite needing to take a break from my masochistic spa day, I am feeling much more optimistic about someday tossing the old triple-blade razor!! The little light does help with the super fine hairs, and this thing DOES find the really, really short ones. I even showed my hubby (and, God love him, he pretended he cared) the root of a very, very short hair.<br /><br />Here's to hair-free days. Or, at the very least, less hairy days! I strongly recommend this product, and I've only owned it for 8 hours!!ES find the really, really short ones. I even showed my hubby (and, God love him, he pretended he cared) the root of a very, very short hair. Here's to hair-free days. Or, at the very least, less hairy days! I strongly recommend this product, and I've only owned it for 8 hours!!

  903. Bought this as a Christmas gift for myself off Amazon last December. Used it a few times, and then had to stop--the shift from shaving to epilating created a GIGANTIC ingrown hair (!) problem. It's been over a year since I bought the machine, and about 8 months since I stopped using it. I still have healing areas on my legs which are red and angry, and severe scarring--lots of discolored white areas that I'm worried won't return to skin color. I don't know if I have extra sensitive skin or something (would be news to me) but SERIOUSLY consider if the risk is worth it before buying this! I was excited to save money/hassle, but now I'm embarrassed to wear shorts. I regret using this.

  909. I'll start with the good aspects of this product. First of all, it really does grab a lot of the hair and the bright light does show the fine hairs. Now for the bad...the so called massaging rollers are actually little tiny spikes that feel almost like they're scratching, oh and as everyone knows...pulling hair out DOES HURT like hell and the body parts you use it on will get irritated...as with any epilator, but there are ways to minimize this problem. The braun 5270 does grab most of the hairs, especially the thick ones, but sadly, some of the fine hairs were left behind and some of the other hairs broke in half.   911. I'm an African-American woman with dark, noticeable hair on my arms, legs and so on. I bought this on a lark for $40 when Amazon had it as part of a Gold Box promotion. Waxing was too expensive and shaving was too time-consuming and inconvenient. I had never epilated before and some of the reviews scared me. I tried it and immediately thought, \\"what in the world was I thinking?!\\" It hurt like you-know-what.<br /><br />After a few tries, this is what I've learned. You really do have to shave first with the accompanying razor. The hair on my legs was visible, but not really long. BUT THE LONGER THE HAIR IS, THE MORE IT HURTS! So shave first, then epilate, then keep epilating every few days or as needed. Also, don't give up if you see hair in a day or two. As another reviewer explained, you've got thousands of little pores/follicles on your skin and hair grows at different rates. So just because you see hair on your legs two days after you epilated does NOT mean it's the same pore/follicle from before. Keep doing it and you'll achieve uniformity.<br /><br />Where I was initially ready to pack up this epilator and send it back, I now can epilate in areas I NEVER thought I'd even try. The result is smooth, hairless skin, just in time for the spring and summer. The product works very well and the light is a nice feature to see the really fine hairs. The ONLY reason I didn't give it 5 stars is that I wish it was quieter. Otherwise, I'm really happy with my purchase.

After daily shaving of my sideburns, chin, and partial neck, it would grow back prickly and some even dark. I had to keep it up and became a prisoner to shaving. About 4 years ago, I bit the bullet and paid for laser hair removal. This cost me nearly 1000 dollars, and was VERY painful (even though they tell you that it is not.) Because my facial hair is light and I have very fair skin, this did little to nothing even after a year and a half of treatments! I went back to shaving and just gave up thinking this was something I'd just make part of my daily routing on vacations, at home, etc. THAT IS until I decided to buy this a few weeks ago. I used it on my face the evening after I did my morning shave, and it removed a LOT of hair. Not really painful either! I thought my legs hurt WAY more. I did NOT shave the following morning, and repeated this for three days. I am completely hair free, folks!!! It has been over 3 weeks and I still am hair free! The only hair that is coming back is super fine and light. This thing is a god send, it really is. I recommend that anyone that is worried about facial hair try this thing out. It may hurt slightly at first, but it is nothing compared to laser and the results are SO worth any discomfort. I am so glad I finally found my answer. I can't wait until our next tropical vacation where I'm not a slave to the razor.

  918. Okay, even though I gave this product five stars, I have to admit that I struggled between 4 and 5. I really like the Epilator. The light on it is very helpful, and it's easy to clean. But for it to be completely effective, you really have to be dedicated and patient. Here are some tips: <br />1. WAIT. I don't care how excited you are to use it... if your leg hairs aren't long enough (2-5mm)... it will just get most of them, and then you'll be using it for days and obsessing over every little hair on your leg. <br />2. Expect ingrown hairs. How do you deal with them? Take a razor and shave in the same direction as hair growth. THEN epilate. Otherwise, it's recommended that you take a warm bath before epilating and/or spread lotion on your legs afterward to avoid the ingrown hairs. <br />3. Epilating your armpits is completely worth it. If you find yourself wondering why the hell you're putting your poor pits through such agony, think: you'll never feel this pain again, because next time, the hair will be much lighter and that won't even be for at least three weeks. <br />Overall, I'm so happy that my boyfriend found the idea of an epilator and showed it to me, because now, every time I get in the shower, I don't think, \\"darn, I haven't shaved in a while. I should really shave, but I don't have the time,\\" and regret it later.

I am going to wait until they grow out and then use this to rid them from my body! Aril 10 I have now taken off the massage head and now use only the advanced head. This still is such a great way to remove hair!

  967. A friend of mine recommended this to me since I like waxing and this would save me $$$ in waxing products. I am used to wax my bikini area and legs, but not my armpits (I shave my armpits). As soon as I got this, I took a warm shower and exfoliate the areas I was going to use this product. I used it on my bikini area and it worked really nice as if I had waxed. The pain was horrible; it was worst than waxing. However, it was a bearable pain. Now, when I started using it under my arms, ooooooouchhhhhhh!!! It hurts like nothing else. It was very painful, but I managed to finish the job under both arms. It took me over 30 mins to do everything because I was taking deep breaths and taking breaks as well. I didn't have a chance to do my legs like I wanted too because I was burning under my arms. It is next day and my armpits are still red and still has some hair in it. I guess I will wait a few days to get back under my arms with the epilator. I will try getting my legs done tonight. It is not a bad product. You just need to learn how to use it and bear the pain. My friend made a good point about all this. She said using the epilator in my bikini area didn't hurt much because I am used to waxing that area and the hair is not so thick. Now, under my arms, the hair was thicker from shaving and therefore the pain was greater. Also, if you stretch your skin as you move the epilator, the pain is also minimal.
  968. I purchased the Braun Silk-epil X'elle at the end of June after reading many of the reviews on Amazon for this product for about 3 weeks. I decided to take the plunge and buy it, since it got such high ratings. Now, had I reviewed this product within the first week of using it, I probably would have rated it 4 stars, but I figured that in the effort of fairness, I would try it out for a full month. I have rated it a total of 3 stars -- here is a breakdown of the positives and negatives I've encountered thus far. Keep in mind that this is the first time I have ever epilated. I am not a waxer and while I occasionally plucked with tweezers, this is the first time I have removed hair by the roots a lot at a time. The positives: - The light! It was not a major selling point at the time I purchased it, but it is extremely handy. Even when I have the bathroom lights on, it can be hard to see the hairs on my legs (and I'm brunette) so this came in really handy. - It's not painful on the legs. Even the bikini line is tolerable, but after trying out my underarms, I know that I'll just stick to my legs. - It lasts about 1.5 weeks. I LOVE that I don't have to shave every couple of days. So even though I have a long list of negatives, I probably would still buy this (but just barely) for the price I paid of $58.43. I wish I knew if some of the cheaper epilators would have gotten the job done for less, but it's too late for that now... so here is my list of negatives: The negatives: - It is very loud. I have two young kids and it is so loud that I would only consider epilating when they are not sleeping or taking naps. - The massaging roller clip. To me it is awkward and doesn't prevent any more pain than the efficiency clip. - The shaver attachment. I am really disappointed with this one. Before I purchased this item, I justified my purchase by thinking that if I couldn't handle epilating, at least I would have an electric shaver which I had been thinkingabout getting anyway. When I found that epilating my underarms was a little too painful for me, I tried using the shaver attachment. It doesn't shave as quickly or effortlessly like I had hoped. In order to shave my underarms closely, I really had to press the shaver attachment onto the skin in quick, repetitive movements. It is SO much easier to just use a disposable razor for my underarms. - Ingrown hairs. At first, I didn't see any, but after 1.5 weeks, I started noticing that quite a few hairs were becoming ingrown. When I used to shave with a disposable razor, I never had this problem. In order to get the ingrown hairs out, I have had to break my skin and pluck them out. This then tends to leave a tiny scab that takes about a week to heal. This means that although my legs are mostly hairless, I have little scabs on them that make it look like I was attacked by mosquitos. - The need to go over the same area more than once. I read the directions and held the epilator as it recommended, but I still find myself going over the same area usually at least twice. This doesn't annoy me too much. - I wish this was cordless. I knew it was corded, but realized that it would be so much nicer if this could be cordless with a rechargable battery. That would allow the flexibility of shaving wherever, and not necessarily where there is a power outlet. - I also wish that there was a way of it storing the hair that it pulls out so that I could then clean the unit easily. Instead, the hairs it pulls out end up wherever -- the floor, my legs, or the unit itself.
  969. I gave this 5 stars because it does exactly what is says it's supposed to do. I was sick and tired of having those dark shadows on my underarms from shaving so I decided to give this a try. I didn't want to wait forever to have the hair grow out to get it waxed. I've used this product 5 times over the last few weeks and it works very, very well. However, IT HURTS! My husband has to do it, because I can't. Each time it has become a little easier, but it still hurts. Keep in mind it's like 40 tweezers spinning at rapid speed ripping the hair out of the most sensitive part of your body by the root, it's going to hurt just a little. Be prepared, buy the cream too.

I use it on my bikini area and it seems that it's not working as well as before. I think it's breaking some of the hair instead of pulling it out because I need to do this about once a week (still beats paying for waxing). Also, I've noticed I get fewer ingrown hairs so I think my skin is getting used to it.<br /><br />Now that the hairs are thinner, the epilator isn't catching them as well so they're breaking. I've decided to alternate this and shaving because shaving is quicker. But what's nice is that my hairs are thinner and lighter so if I miss a shave or don't epilate for a week, it's not too noticeable (doesn't feel prickly and doesn't look hairy).

  974. I've always been a Braun fan and probably bought the first model made. After 12+ years, the port for the plug finally gave out and I decided to try the newer model. I can't assess pain, because I have a high pain tolerance and have never had any problem with tweezing. I love the newer look, and it is SO MUCH better at pulling the hairs. Where the old model I had to go over the area a few times to get all the hair, I only have to do 1-2 swipes to get everything. The light is ok for just seeing the area in front of where your going, but is distracting for seeing a larger area overall. But if you just use good lighting or sunlight, then you don't need the light and it fades away in the background. The only downside, is that the plastic head (that clicks over the top of the rollers to keep them from directly contacting your skin)is not very secure and pops off if you press too firmly.   975. I have used an earlier version of Braun before, and this one was just so much more sophisticated. The smartlight is a wonderful feature. I used it for my hands and both hands were done in about 15 minutes. There is pain, but not much. I first used the massaging rollers option, then switched to the faster epilation- this is really good and tweezes very small hair too! I havent used the opti-trim attachment yet, and dont think I will dare to use the epilator on the underarm area. Another plus is that it works across 110-250 volts, so there is no need for a voltage converter if you are a globe trotter. It is best that you use this product once in 10 days to remain virtually hair free. The time consuming part is cleaning the tweezers with alcohol once youre done using it. Wish there was a dip or something that could magically get rid of all bacteria! Overall, a good investment- A very good, quick epilator for the legs, arms and bikini line. Leaves your skin much smoother than shaving and regrowth takes time too!

  984. After reading review on many epilator machines, I settled on this one. The epilator is relatively inexpensive, ergonomically designed, the attachments are handy and it comes with a bag to put everything in after use, the light is very helpful in finding the hairs, and there are no annoying batteries to replace. I used it on my legs first and was able to finish both legs in about 40 min. In the future, it won't take me as long since I was going really slow this first time trying the epilator out. It's great bc unlike shaving, it doesn't leave little black dots where the hair used to be. Your legs won't feel as smooth as if you just shaved, but they stay relatively smooth for weeks instead of getting prickly in two days. Besides, you can always do a quick shave after for super smooth skin. I did both underarms in 15 min and unlike waxing, it got every single hair and there was no bleeding from the hair follicles. I think this machine does really well with thicker hair. The hair on my legs is fine and so I missed a few here and there, but the results on the underarms were fantastic. The only thing is that I would not use any of the epilators on the face, even the ones \\"made\\" for use on facial hair as they seem to cut more strands of hair than pluck. Other than that, I'm ecstatic about this new find. It will definitely save me tons of $ on wax and shaving equipment.
  985. I bought this little number mostly because I had grown tired of bikini waxes. While there are certainly a few pluses to this epilator compared to waxing (your hair can be shorter, at home use), this little machine's revolving tweezers are more painful than a bikini wax. This baby is also rather intimidatingly noisy and scary when you first turn it on; it doesn't inspire confidence about putting it anywhere near your lady-parts. I found that the first epilation was by far the worst, but that after that initial shock-and-awe hair-removal the pain was way less. For me the result was just as good as a bikini wax. The pain for leg-hair removal was negligible and it does make a big difference regarding how frequently I need to shave my gams. All in all a good investment- just be prepared for some wincing.
  986. This product works great! I just used it for the first time and it really is VERY painful however, it pulls out ALL of the hairs at the root.   987. I am of German descent. If I shave with a razor, in 5-8 hours (or if I get a chill), I will have a \\"five 'o'clock shadow\\" on my legs. I can normally go maybe 2 days, tops, before the new growth is obvious enough that I can't get away with wearing a skirt to work. Let me say this - I am NOT a waxer. I was genuinely terrified of the potential pain of systematically ripping out every hair on my leg. The Braun epilator is absolutely awesome! First, the scary. I won't lie. The first time you use it, it will hurt. Try to keep the roller perfectly perpendicular to the surface area you are rolling across. It helps if you roll backwards and forwards across each area a couple of times. If you have worked on one area of your leg for too long, try giving that area a \\"break\\" for awhile and move on to your other leg. Using the included freezer bag thing helped to numb the areas a little at first, but after a while I figured it was easier without. Mostly, you'll just have to grin and bear it the first time you epilate. But you can get through it! A note: I've found that it helps to pull your skin taut as you epilate. The areas that are easiest for me are those areas where the skin is closer to the bone, contrary to what you might think. It's the more \\"fleshy\\" areas, like my thighs, that are awful. I still don't epilate my thighs, for that reason. Not only is my skin there more sensitive, but the hair tends to be softer and have a tougher time ripping out up there, which probably contributes to the pain. But, that being said, I am not a terribly athletic person. I suspect that if you're toned, you'll do fine. Once you're through the initial trial run, the next times you use it, it will just get easier and easier. Now it's like using an electric razor, with an only slightly annoying plucking. Don't set your expectations too high. Keep in mind that your hair is constantly growing in cycles, yadda yadda. So don't expect your legs to feel smoothas a baby's behind after your epilate. There's always going to be some stickery growth that is too short to yank out just yet.... but the good news is that it's too short to see at all. I don't care so much about feeling perfectly smooth, I just want to be able to wear a skirt to work, or go to the pool, etc. without having to shave every single day. Goal accomplished! Here are all the reasons I love my Braun epilator (wow, I should really do an infomercial....) : 1. I epilated on Monday night. It's now Friday night, and I still can't see the growth!!! I wore short shorts today. 2. The light is quite helpful. It's nearly impossible to miss any hairs. 3. Once you're used to it, it goes pretty quickly. 4. No razor burn! If you have pasty white skin like me, you might have a little redness. This is why I use the epilator at night. Then I put a little lotion with aloe on my legs. In the morning - good as new for a week! 5. No more buying razors, except for my armpits and very sensitive areas (using the epilator there would just be masochistic, in my opinion). I have effectively gone from buying razors once a week to once every 3-4 months. 6. I can appreciate a well-designed product. Fits into your hand very well and is comfortable. And the sparklies are preeeetty! ^_^ 7. Well worth the price, when you consider that a really good electric razor will cost you around $80, and if you're like me, you'd have to use that every single day.

  992. I was a little nervous after reading all the reviews, but decided to go ahead and give it a try. I really didn't find it unbearably painful at all! Nor do I have chicken bumps which is a surprise since I always got them when using an electric shaver. If I had tried to do an entire leg in one run I'm sure I'd feel differently, for me stopping for a few moments after every pass was the trick, then after 2-3 passes as I become familiar with the sensations. Sure, this means it took longer than shaving, however this will reduce over time and I don't have any nicks like I usually end up with using a disposable razor or pain and bumps afterward like I do with an electric shaver. I should probably also point out that although I was very careful to maintain the 90 degree angle I did barely touch the skin (no pressure at all) and moved slowly up my lower leg for each pass. I have no clue if those that complained of unbearable pain or injury were using a different technique or if I'm just lucky... My hair grows in thick (I certainly qualify for ape-legs if I don't do something about it) however each strand is thin/fine (the hair on my legs is a red-brown) and my skin is sensitive and very very pale if this makes any difference (hair coarseness and/or thickness seems to somehow be relevant from other posts).

  999. I had this epilator for 5 years before I finally had to replace it. It only started slowing down because I was epilating my legs while wearing socks, and it snagged on an elastic from my sock which tangled it up. Even though I thought I pulled all of the elastic back out, it just didn't work right after that. But for $54, that's ~$10/year vs however much I would have spent on razors and shaving cream.<br /><br />Other than that, I have loved this epilator since I got it. The light is very convenient for seeing all of the hairs. I never considered buying an electric shaver, but the shaver attachment has come in handy when I didn't expect it to. I've never really used the efficiency head. The massage rollers also help to prep your skin before they get plucked. When I'm not careful while getting the arm pit area, it sometimes snags on my skin, but I think that's because it's an awkward angle with loose skin.<br /><br />Overall it works well and is able to get a lot of short hairs easily. It leaves my skin feel very smooth, and even the hairs that grow back feel fine as well and take awhile to grow back. I usually do not see any hair regrowth for at least 1.5 weeks.
  1000. I love my epilator. I tell people I haven't shaved in at least 7 years and they freak out, but then I soothe their crazy minds to tell them I epilate. After I explain epilating they freak out again thinking I'm crazy, but hey, I used to use tweezers and pluck out each and every armpit hair and would occasionally do the same for my legs... this epilator invention is genius for crazies like me. Don't get me wrong, I still pluck, but the epilator makes large areas much easier.<br /><br />When using this, it needs to be kept in mind it should be used as if it's waxing treatments. I was doing it whenever I'd get hairy, which is like every three days, and it was pretty much as often as shaving. I was all annoyed that I was hairy beast woman even when pulling hairs out from the root, but then managed to hold out a couple months long enough for the 2-weeks to see if it would make a difference. It really did! I now epilate the 1st and the 15th of the month (give or take a few days if I can't handle the itchiness and the *doink doink doink* of hairs when it's cold) and I stay relatively smooth for at least a week. When the hair grows in, though I can feel them all freak out when it's cold or I'm getting out of the shower, the hairs are so fine they aren't visible to any normal person. It helps that I'm 2 feet from the ground, so any freakish man looking at my legs deserves to see the yeti fur, but in any case after 7 years of this, yeah, what I was saying, the hair is mighty fine.
  1001. I'm struggling with this epilator. As mentioned by others, it's true that epilating is not a pain free option for hair removal, but I think the pain is minimal on the legs and not bad on the underarms. It's more painful than waxing for all areas, but particularly the bikini area, and takes much longer. I find that it doesn't pull all the hairs out cleanly, so I'm left with some broken hairs that create stubble. I do use it on the bikini area (although some areas are really painful) and I'm getting a lot of ingrown hairs which I never get with waxing. Other reviews have said to persevere, so I'll give it a few more tries, but I'm not ecstatic about it - it's just a cheaper option than salon waxing and less messy than if you do home waxing.

That's the only reason it gets 4 rather than 5 stars.

  1013. This will respond to the question as to how well it works for men. I have been regularly removing my chest hair by waxing, but, since waxing always leaves a few hairs behind, I'd always have to follow up for a few days, as time allowed, to finish up with a pair of tweezers. Since time is at a premium these days, I wondered if this thing might be an effective alternative. I just tried it today, and man! I hit the jackpot! I was done in about five minutes, and cleared just about everything away. Previous postings made reference to pain -- in my case, I felt NO pain. The sensation was definitely odd at first, then not noticeable at all. I was able to really press it close against my skin to get at the tiniest hairs. More effective than waxing, in a lot less time, and no pain. Outstanding!
  1014. I received my epilator in the mail today. I decided to try it out on my arms first (because I had just shaved my legs yesterday). While it hurt at first, I either my arm became numb or I just got used to it. This was MUCH less painful than when I got my tattoo on my ankle. :) I was able to remove the hair on both forearms in about ten minutes. 1-1/2 hours later and the skin on my arms still hurts, but it is bearable. It feels somewhat like a slight sunburn. Even though I was using this in our bathroom right by the ten vanity bulbs, I'm glad that the Braun epilator 5270 has the bright light because it let me see all of the hairs that I couldn't see with our regular lights. The cord was long enough to give me room to move around a little and it is very pliable so that it didn't get in the way while using the epilator. Cleaning the epilator after using it on my arms was pretty straightforward. I was AMAZED to see how much hair it had collected. I used to have to take an analgesic and a glass of wine or two before I would even consider epilating my legs. I seriously had to talk myself into it. It was almost as painful as waxing. Now, epilating is almost pain free and this prodcuct takes less than half the time to use. The areas that are terribly sensitive for me - my ankles, knees, shinbone area, and upper thigh were so painful that even after the wine I would grit my teeth and have to power through. I just used the Braun for the 2nd time and it was so easy, quick, and pain free. The Epilady would grab my hair and only partially pull it out - resulting in unnecessary pain and having to go over the same hair several times. This caused the whole process to be frustrating, time intensive, terribly painful, and I would end up with ingrown hairs. This product is fabulous. I don't mind epilating at all now and actually almost enjoy it! I am sure the novelty of pain free epilating will wear off, however, this product is an answer to all my needs and I am delighted to have found it. If you are new to epilating, this will be uncomfortable at first but once you are used to it and your hair comes out more easily (this happens over time), you will find that this doesn't hurt at all. This is a wonderful product.

  1022. I think the other reviews have mostly covered the epilation side of this, but: It really isn't as scary as it seems. I'd heard from a few people who'd previously tried epilating that it's excruciatingly painful, they all gave up on it almost immediately after they bought it, &c. And i'm not great with pain myself, so i was nervous. But it's not that bad. It does hurt, i can't deny that, but it's tolerable. The best way i can describe the sensation is this: When i was younger i would steal my father's electric shaver to use on my legs, and since i didn't know how to use it very well i would push it too hard into my skin in an effort to shave closer. I pushed it so hard that i could feel the blades on the other side of the grill nipping at my skin. That's what epilating feels like. I do have a few pain-management tips if you find that it's too much: 1. Take some ibuprofen or naproxen 15 minutes before starting. 2. Stretch your skin taut, as far as it will go (don't hurt yourself obviously). This is especially helpful around the calves. 3. (And this is the most important one!) Don't be delicate! You will probably feel the urge to take quick little nips and then pull the epilator away -- don't do this, it just makes it hurt more (plus it takes longer). It seems counter-intuitive, but keep it in contact with your skin the whole time. Do one little spot at a time, in tiny circular or back-and-forth motions, and when it's completely finished move slowly to the next spot. OK, aside from the actual act of epilating: - The epilator feels fine in your hand. It seemed bigger in the picture to me than it really was, so if it looks really chunky to you too, don't worry. - It hasn't got a battery, it will only run off the mains. The cable it comes with is probably long enough for most people, but if you're like me and your tub is on the opposite side of the bath room from the wall socket (and you don't want to get hair all over your floor), you might need ashort extension cord. - Contrary to the other reviews, i have found the shaver attachment to be extremely poor. I am not a regular user of electric shavers, but i have tried a couple over the years, so i feel i have a basis for comparison. This one is just awful to the point of being useless. It will trim the hairs, eventually, so they're short enough to epilate, but it will take AGES (it'd probably be faster to use cuticle scissors...). It will NOT get close enough to do the job of a normal shaver. So if you're thinking to yourself (as i was), 'oh hey, this is a sure thing, even if i don't like the epilator i'll still have a perfectly good shaver!', you should probably rethink it. It's fine if you just want the epilator, but don't factor the shaver into the equation at all, because it's worthless.
  1023. After reading the reviews on the different Epilators I finally chose the Braun 5270. It has the best reviews by far. For me, unfortunately, things did not work out as I had hoped. I had waxed before the Epilator so I thought pain would not be an issue. IT IS !!! The Epilator REALLY hurts and I do not have thick hair. Also I noticed that no matter what attachment I use I do not get a complete shave. Little tiny micro hairs remain and after going through such an ordeal that is pretty frustrating. I can not say don't purchase this but I will say do not have great expectations. Hope this helps future buyers

  1027. Let me start this by giving my stats: I have very fair skin and very dark hair (dark brown/black hair). I also have sensitive skin. I bought this for the same reason everyone else did: to never shave again. I was intrigued by the promise of being hair-free for weeks at a time. And also thought the idea of this being less and less painful was a plus. Well, sadly, I didn't get the results I expected. I have have been using this product for three weeks now (every day at first, then every other day), and here's what's happened (from top to bottom): Underarms - I suffer from \\"the shadow\\" and thought this would be a good way to get rid of that. Wrong. The first time I used this it was way more painful than waxing and caused my underarms to bleed in every spot the hair was pulled from. Needless to say, I have gone back to waxing. Forearms - I also suffer from dark hair here. The removal is painful and causes red spots where the hair has been pulled out. But it does remove that \\"shadow\\" that shaving left behind. I do have to use it daily, and I have been using it for 3 weeks. Apparently, I have hair growing constantly. But, on the plus side, I do not have ingrown hairs. Legs - this was the major disappointment. The first time I used this, I only used it on my lower legs and knees. It was so painful, but it did pull out hairs. My legs were so splotchy from where the hair had been removed. So, I decided to only use the epilator on my lower legs for one week, then move onto the thighs. (Never intended to use it on the bikini line...ouch!). So, I used it everyday for a week, and still hair kept growing. It has been three weeks now and hair is still growing everyday like I had never epilated the day before. I tried using it on my thighs but it was too painful for me to handle. The one thing that was nice at first is my legs didn't have that dark undergrowth that shaving can leave. However, I have noticed this past week that half of each of my lower legs are covered in ingrown hairs. It's really bad. Even my husband couldn't believe it. I do exfoliate in the shower, so I can only assume the epilation has caused it. (I did some research and found out that epliation does cause more ingrown hairs than shaving or waxing.) So, I will go back to shaving my legs. Feet and toes - No problem here. Minor pain and the hair actually stays gone! Overall, not worth the money. I will continue to use it on my forearms and feet/toes. The pain has never improved and is just as painful as the first day I used it. I can say if you epilate at night, the splotches are gone by morning. I hope this product works better for others.
  1028. I purchased this item exactly 7 months back. I wanted to fully test it before I write a review. In three simple words - I LOVE IT!! I already had a Braun Epilator (older generation) but I wanted an epilator which worked in the US voltage conditions. After reading all the reviews I was deciding between Panasonic and the newer Braun epilator. I ended up choosing this one as \\"known devil is better than unknown\\". I couldn't have made a better choice! First and foremost, what I noticed is that this is much quieter & efficient than the older generation. Secondly, this epilator has light (\\"SmartLight\\") on the button where you push-to-start. This helps me tremendously when I want to remove fine hairs in a low light condition (evenings, nights, bathrooms etc.). I had read that there were couple of reviewers/ users who disliked it or never found it useful. That wasn't the case with me, at all! I was wary of this statement but took a chance anyway. Now my hands feel as if they never had any hairs at all! No more seeing random hairs when you stand in the sunlight! This also comes with 2 attachments - one for fine hairs and one for coarse hairs (shaving attachment). Depends where you have what! It also comes with two speeds. For me, speed 1 is good enough. Speed two is if you want it gone faster. It also comes with the EfficiencyPro clip (the blue part on the attachment which cushions when you epilate). I found that this helps in angling the machine in such a way that skin doesn't get trapped in the tweezers. Compared to my older generation Braun this one gets the job done in half the time and much less pain! I would recommend this to everyone without any hesitation.

  1039. Oh man....it, um.....was better than the one other time I tried it in the early 90's, I must say. This new Braun model I tried has little massagers that basically do a Shiatsu-like beating of the skin before using their 40 tweezer action to rip it out, and the result feels more like sandpaper or a coarse sugar scrub applied vigorously. Surprisingly very tolerable. <I can't tolerate waxing, but have gone for laser hair removal; the business went under so I'm left with tiny hairs - everyone is left with light hairs after laser treatments - and a few (30 or so) long dark grandma ones were growing back in a sea of tiny fine blonde ones. I actually felt it more (kind of numb & a little tender) AFTER I was completely done with the first leg. It's fine now, after only 2 hours, and it lasted less than 20 minutes for me. Well worth it if the hair does indeed stay gone for a while, as that's clearly what I was going for! :) The industry has seen a vast improvement!

The only thing I would like better is if it was cordless as I like to epilady outdoors & it would be more convenient not to be near a power source. Overall it is a great product that I will use forever.

I previously had the new rechargeable wet/dry version which started having problems after just about 2 months and couldn't hold a charge for more than a minute. This version though is so much more powerful, and does a much better job of removing all the hair with less passes. I hadn't used an epilator since the horribly torturous epilady, when I was a teenager. The new ones are much easier and pain-free to use. It did hurt the initial time I began to epilate again, but by the second use I was completely fine. So much better than waxing and easy to go back in case you missed anything.
  1043. My first epilator was a Braun Silk-epil. I liked it a lot, but switched to the Emjoi. I loved my Emjoi but they stopped making the exact model (of which I purchased two over the years). I have been using one or the other of these devices for approx. 10 years now. One of my Emjois quit recently, so I needed to purchase a new one (I keep one at work and one at home). As I said, they quit making the exact model of Emjoi, so I had to do some research. I purchased the Braun 5270 after reading about it. I like it a lot. It is a fast epilator. It works a little better than the Emjoi, but it has a tendency to pinch my skin in the more sensitive areas (like bikini line and underarms). Yes, I use it everywhere! This kinda bugs me, but it works so well everywhere else, I'm learning to be more cautious. This is why I gave this unit 4 stars instead of 5. If it didn't pinch, the light would make this unit a 5+. I'm getting a little older and my hair is blonde. I've been epillating for so many years that my hair grows in very fine and is hard to see. I used to need my reading lamp (and my reading glasses) to get all of the hairs. I still need the glasses, but not the lamp. The light sillouettes (it actually puts a little halo around the hairs) the hair so I can see them all. It's the best feature! I do recommend this unit, just be careful of the pinching. If you are only going to use this on your legs, this is definitely the unit for you.
  1044. I purchased a less expensive brand - Revlon - from a television shopping show. It did not work as well as the Braun and within weeks after getting it the bearings in the swivel arm began to fall out. The Braun is far superior to any other models I have tried. It is better made, hair removal is cleaner and closer to the skin, has a light that helps you see the area you are working on. I strongly recommend this product - Braun has been making razors and epilators for a long time. They have the history of being tried and true producing quality products. Do not waste your money on any other epilator--Braun may cost a little more initially- you will save more in the long run in money and time.
  1045. First, let me start off by saying that compliance on feedback is extremely difficult (unless the product is outrageously fabulous or garbage), so the fact that 700+ people have actually come on here and left feedback is telling. The fact that 700+ people bought it and it has a user rating of 4.5 is outstanding and statistically powerful. Okay, enough with the numbers, once you get past the difficult stuff (more on that shortly), it's a very effective product and well worth the 50 bucks I paid (less than one session for a brazilian). The 'difficult' stuff would be: 1) It really is pretty painful (and I thought I had high pain tolerance) but you do get used to it little by little 2) The bikini area is definitely the most painful 3) you have to keep the gadget moving in strokes because if you stall to long in place it tends to grab the skin 4) keep the skin taught!! (otherwise it won't grab) 5) Ladies, not good if you have upper lip hair...way to bulky to get in there 6) I read a lot of people on here that said do this after a shower...well I beg to differ. Actually, doing it after the shower gave me insane razor rash. In my experience, the after shower stuff makes it worse. So in summary, it is a really great alternative to laser treatment or waxes. Get it!

I've now used it about three times, and already it doesn't come back the same. Sure, I've gotten some ingrown hairs, and its a little red and bumpy after, but use lotion! Exfoliate a lot, and use lotion everyday after you shower, and it helps. To me, its worth the trouble. I have crazy hairy legs that I used to shave every or every other day and it totally sucked. With this thing, even while I wait for it to grow back out after epilating, it doesn't seem as bad, and I still wear shorts and stuff. So, if you are hairy, and can suck it up, just think about how much cheaper this is compared to a summer of razors, or getting waxed all the time, or getting that permanent hair removal. Plus, nair sucks, and we all have to realize there isn't a pain free way to get rid of hair unless you shave.

  1054. My advice is as follows: get this product and commit to using it for several weeks at least. You need to use it that long before you'll reap the full benefits. It's an excellent tool and should be used as a part of your routine- NOT as a quick \\"I'm going out tonight and need a shave\\" type thing. In fact don't do that. It can leave you with blood spotting and red bumps, just like waxing can, so give yourself a night or two to recover. Step one if you're just getting started... Give yourself a light shave first- don't go close, just a basic, light shave and don't worry about being stubbly. Wait a night. I found that using the epilator for the first time was less daunting and painful on veeeeery short, recently shaved hairs and it gave me time to get used to the device. The tweezers actually go in and grab short stubble, so no need to wait for long length as with wax. Just go ahead and use it on a day or two old shave. So commit to it. Make sure the skin is held taut and that it's clean and dry. Do expect some pain. I personally didn't find my legs to be very painful at all, but the bikini area...well that does indeed take some determination, especially if you intend to get really bare down there. You just have to work through the pain and make sure you hold all that skin VERY taut and safely out of the way. I went for it on the higher setting and did not bother with the lower speed at all. The result is worthwhile, especially if you get itchy razor bumps like I do from shaving. Do small areas at a time if you need to. I was basically epilating tiny stubble and was amazed at how LONG the hairs that came out were. This thing seriously does pluck out hair all the way down, so it's effective. Do small sections every day if you need to or go for the whole area at once. You can do it. It gets easier the longer you epilate, and no doubt your body starts producing endorphins in response to the pain. The device is a little bit loud and your hand will vibrate a bit afterward, but I would certainly buy it again. Use it everyday to get rid of various patches of stray stubble as soon as they pop up- after a few cycles all will be smooth and calm.
  1055. This Braun epilator works much better than the older model I had. It seems to spin much faster and is more effective at removing the hair. I like the shaving attachment too. I took one star off because its still not perfect at removing all the hair and its very noisy too.
  1056. I LOVE LOVE LOVE this thing. I've done the whole shaving thing for years, but it hurts like heck to shave over stubble, especially \\"down there\\". So I've done the waxing thing...painful, missed a lot of hairs, and hated having to grow it out for so long before I could wax. So I finally dropped the money for one of these, and let me tell you, I'll never go back to anything else. Does it hurt...yes. But once you see how well it works, even getting rid of the hairs that were too short to wax, you will be hooked. I don't think it was too much worse than waxing...same sensation but more drawn out. On certain parts of your body it's more painful, like the back of my calves, \\"down there\\" and underarms, at times it felt like a burning sensation, but only lasted a few seconds, and the results were so worth it. It has now been over a week, and I've only had to \\"touch up\\" once. For some reason, the hair on my legs doesn't all grow in at the same rate, and the nice thing about this is that you can use it jut like any other razor, and just do the spots you need, instead of trying to wax random spots where the hair grew back in, and unlike shaving, you wont have to worry about it for awhile. The only complaint I have is that the attachment that has the bead type massage things broke on one side. I think I was able to find all the beads that fell off, and can probably repair it myself, if not I probably wont even bother taking it back, I don't think I would use that attachment all that much anyways....But to wrap this up...AWESOME product, no regrets what-so-ever, and if it ever quits on me I'll buy another one in a heartbeat!
  1057. I have had this epilator since last year and I absolutely love it! The first few times it hurt a little but now I am used to the pain. I am an indian girl with thick black hair on my legs and arms. I use this epilator and I am hair free for a few weeks! In between I do some touch-ups but the hair has been taking longer to grow back. Plus its finer so even if I have some hair which I forget to epilate, you can't notice it. It is very easy to use and clean. It is a bit loud but nothing that bad. For cleaning it, I take the brush, dip it in alcohol and wipe the entire surface of the epilator. I use a safety pin to get the hair that gets trapped inside the little holes in the cartridge that pulls the hair out. Doing that is time consuming but it keeps the device functioning perfectly. I have recommended it to my mom and a few friends who have all bought and loved it. I have not used this on my face and I will not because I have sensitive facial skin.

  1060. This is a very good, versatile hair removal device. Once you're used to the minor pain of the tweezing, it's a dream. Just like waxing but with only a fraction of the cost over time. Additionally you can do this at home with a minimal amount of time. Forget shaving your legs every day!<br /><br />Epilating your bikini area or under arms I do not advise. The hairs there are coarser and much more committed to staying in your skin than leg hair. Subsequently, I feel like this device ends up just pulling AT them and not pulling them OUT which is considerably more painful than leg hair coming out, and also not as effective.<br /><br /> That being said, I'm sure some of you can take it! For these areas the shaving/buzzer attachment does a good (but not perfectly smooth) job of getting those hairs down to size. I'd say keep your brazilian wax appointments if you want to be totally smooth, but this is a great solution for everything else!

  1064. First things first, let me mention that I'm a dude and I love this machine! My hair is probably thicker than the women out there, and probably more prominent, but the Braun Epilator sucks it up wonderfully, with some pain I admit - but if you continue to use this thing the pain eventually goes away - because so does your hair!<br /><br />Okay, so if you're like me and never heard of an epilator before let me tell you what this does - a bunch of rotating pluckers revolve at a fast pace and essentially rip out your hair at root level. As you can imagine this can be a very painful experience, BUT it doesn't have to be! There are a thousand ways to prevent (or ease) the pain and here are my ways:<br /><br />1. Shave with the epilator's attachment or with regular razor first! The epilator can grab onto tiny, tiny hair follicles! If you can see the hair you waited too long to epilate.<br /><br />2. Epilate EVERY day! You will always have hair growing, but after you pluck one out by the root it takes that individual hair about a week or two to grow back. You will have other hairs appearing the next day after you use your epilator though. It will take a couple of weeks of everyday use, but eventually all your hairs will be taking so long to grow back that you will have beautiful baby-bare skin. ALSO - since shaving with a razor doesn't take out the root, the hair you've had since puberty has had a Long time to set up shop in your skin - this means that the root is going to be fixated in place a lot better than hair that's had to regrow after plucking. This is why the first time users are going to have a lot more pain than the people that use it all the time.<br />*the red bumps first time users have will also get less and less with each use<br /><br />3. Go with the growth - if you start the epilator in the same direction your hair is growing there will be significantly less pain. The problem with this method is that you won't be able to get all the hairs this way, but if you start this way you will remove some hairs and your biggest goal is to have as few hairs at one time going through the epilator's pluckers. It doesn't hurt at all if you're plucking 1 hair, but it starts to feel pretty intense if there's a ton going through it!<br /><br />4. Epilate right after bath or shower - a body that's just been steamed will let loose its hair follicles much easier than a dry, hard body.<br /><br />5. For sensitive areas, pluck with tweezers first - I tried to epilate my \\"Bikini\\" area without plucking first and it was a bad idea. Even though I shaved myself nearly bald before epilating, the hair follicles in my groin were so firmly rooted it was torture to mass pluck them. So, I plucked hairs one at a time with tweezers until I'd taken out over half the growth. After that the epilating was a breeze, and now that the hair growing there is new and not so firmly in place, I can epilate them all without much pain.<br /><br />6. Develop your own technique! Everybody's hair is different and everybody has a different tolerance for this kind of pain. Experiment with the epilator, but don't give up on it. It can truly be your best friend in the battle against unwanted hair.<br /><br />--<br /><br />Overall I can't be more excited enough about this product! I use it for my legs, arms, nipples, and groin and have the long-lasting smooth, hairless skin I've always wanted without ever using razors or wax. The only downside to using this is that your skin will for sure have red bumps for a few hours after you it in some areas. I've noticed this decrease significantly as I continue using it though (probably because my new hair growth is less rooted) but I still see them occasionally, especially on my arms but almost never on my legs. They can also be avoided by using some of my pain-decreasing steps, too.<br /><br />Try it, boys and girls!remove some hairs and your biggest goal is to have as few hairs at one time going through the epilator's pluckers. It doesn't hurt at all if you're plucking 1 hair, but it starts to feel pretty intense if there's a ton going through it! 4. Epilate right after bath or shower - a body that's just been steamed will let loose its hair follicles much easier than a dry, hard body. 5. For sensitive areas, pluck with tweezers first - I tried to epilate my \\"Bikini\\" area without plucking first and it was a bad idea. Even though I shaved myself nearly bald before epilating, the hair follicles in my groin were so firmly rooted it was torture to mass pluck them. So, I plucked hairs one at a time with tweezers until I'd taken out over half the growth. After that the epilating was a breeze, and now that the hair growing there is new and not so firmly in place, I can epilate them all without much pain. 6. Develop your own technique! Everybody's hair is different and everybody has a different tolerance for this kind of pain. Experiment with the epilator, but don't give up on it. It can truly be your best friend in the battle against unwanted hair. -- Overall I can't be more excited enough about this product! I use it for my legs, arms, nipples, and groin and have the long-lasting smooth, hairless skin I've always wanted without ever using razors or wax. The only downside to using this is that your skin will for sure have red bumps for a few hours after you it in some areas. I've noticed this decrease significantly as I continue using it though (probably because my new hair growth is less rooted) but I still see them occasionally, especially on my arms but almost never on my legs. They can also be avoided by using some of my pain-decreasing steps, too. Try it, boys and girls!

  1072. I have been depilating for about three years now and used to be a long time shaver. I will never go back to shaving. I may have shortened the lifespan of it by trying to go over some places I just tried to wax...but nevertheless mine conked out in the middle of my session. The point is my hubbs ran out and got me the Remington to replace this one and it was nowhere as good as this Braun. However if I may spare some first time users some amazing pain by recommending that you get professionally waxed before you start using this product and then use it every other day in the beginning...maybe a month or so. It is absolute torture to use this for the first second and third times if you are hairy then you let it grow back because you are afraid to use it again. The third time I let my hair grow back I went to a spa and got waxed then resumed my usage with the epilator..wow what a difference. Now I epilate only every one to two weeks and it is still mildly uncomfortable but not like it was in the beginning. So take heart brave soldiers and don't give up. You will love this way more than shaving because you won't have those embarrassing prickly legs with hair stubs anymore. Epilated legs (as well as waxed) grow out smooth and soft and fine.   1073. Few months ago, I was on Amazon about to buy another crate of waxing strips when this little product caught my eye (thanks to a well placed ad). I am so happy with it that I just had to write a review, which is not something I often do. First and foremost, it works - it is faster, easier, cheaper, less painful and more efficient than waxing. I used to wait a few weeks between waxings to let the hairs grow out in order to get more bang out of a waxing session, and this would mean having to wear long pants and avoiding pool pretty often. Well, no more - now I use the epilator for 15 minutes once a week and never have any noticeable hair. It gets every little hair, I find that even short hairs get zapped efficiently. The light feature is very helpful. In fact, I started epilating my upper legs which used to have thin hair, and now they are actually coming in thicker (or maybe I just see them better with the light). So maybe hold the urge to epilate everything in sight. In terms on pain, I found it to be similar or even less painful than waxing, but I am a long time waxer. It has a special massaging attachment and two speeds to ease you into it, but I did not find those necessary. I have to pass each area several times, but it will get every single hair. Again it is much faster than waxing and there is no mess. The downsides as other people have mentioned is that it is pretty loud so you can't watch TV as you are epilating, and it has to be plugged in (no battery option), but in fact the cord is sufficiently long. Also I did notice a few more ingrown hairs since I started using it, but I should probably just exfoliate more often. I use it in the bikini area - and I define the bikini area as the upper thigh area up to the leg crease, I don't go any further. It is a bit more painful and cumbersome to navigate in that area, but it gets the job done for the most part - I do have to touch up with tweezers. So despite these minor negatives, I give it five thumbs up!! Do not hesitate to buy it - it will set you free!!
  1074. I just got this thing three weeks ago. Yes, using it was painful, but bareable. You have to have a great deal of patience to do your whole legs (and mine are pretty hairy). I am confident this is a great investment for every woman!

  1085. Bought this epilator because it was so highly recommended. Back in the day of coiled epilady machines, it took me 20 min. My previous epilator was Epilady and took ~30 min. I especially hate the fact that you have to repeat an area so many times to get all the hairs in the more sensitive areas, which by the time you are done, are all red and irritated.   1086. It has been 6 months since I purchased this, and I am a true convert from shaving. The only thing better would be lazer hair removal. The first three times it hurt, badly, but the results kept me coming back. I started by using it on my lower legs and arms, but now I use it on upper lip, chin, arms, underarms, and legs/bikini area. If I do it every two weeks, It takes about 2 hours now, well worth it. If I wait 4 weeks it takes twice as long because it hurts. The longer you let the hair grow in between the more it hurts, I suggest shaving 3-4 days before you do it so its not too long, or just keep up with it. I was hoping that I'd be on the once-a-month program like others who posted, but 2 weeks is my maximum, don't want the hair to get too long or numerous or else it hurts that much more when you start up again. But 2 weeks works for me and is well worth it, I haven't picked up a razor in months. I am caucasian with thick dark hair. If you're on the fence, I recommend you go for it! I went on Amazon to research bulk razors/shaving cream 6 months ago, since disposable razors and shaving cream were costing me an arm and a leg, and this popped up in the search results. Having smooth legs for weeks at a time is worth the \\"me time\\" it takes to do this, and I only wish I had started when I was in my teens so that I'd be at a more advanced level by now (after a few years you only have to do this twice a year). The product itself is wonderfully designed for a woman. The cord and plug are nice, friendly white plastic. The item itself hardly weighs anything, and if it weren't for my own squeamishness the time it takes would be cut in half at least. Two speed settings, a nice bright light, it's very nice. Yes, it is a bit loud but that doesn't even matter. I'm not a Braun employee. I used to buy disposable razors and shaving cream, and now I don't have to!
  1087. I've been epilating for about ten years. I was a loyal purchaser of another very popular epilation product similar to the Braun, but the other epilator would slow down over time and not grab as much hair as the Braun. I also found myself purchasing the other epilator every year because it just wouldn't last. With the Braun, I stayed smooth for two weeks and yes, the hair does grow back finer. Epilating is really good for people who have course and, or slightly curled hairs that usually get more ingrown hairs. With epilation, you get less ingrown hairs, and of course stay smoother longer than shaving. You also don't get burned like you can with hair removal creams. It's not completely painless, but after a few strokes, the slight pain you may feel goes away due to the massaging rollers on this product. I suggest you lay down in a comfortable area and relax before you start the epilation process. The Braun is also one of the fastest epilators I've tried and the smart light helps you to see every hair so you don't miss any. The results are worth the little discomfort you may experience. The only slight negative experience is it did slightly pinch my skin once or twice on one epilating session, but it didn't hurt. As a veteran epilator, the Braun 5270 X'elle gets my approval and recommendation.

I know some people had trouble with their hairs not picking up but I'm very fair and have medium dark hair and it worked just fine. I would encourage you to use it at night like suggested as I did get red bumps all over my legs. Exfoliating is also super important, I still have some ingrown hairs in my under arms but in time this will go away.   1090. This was my second epilator....I purchased a less expensive one (by Revlon) the first time around, since I wasn't sure if I would prefer epilation over shaving. Well, I'm hooked! For those of you who have never tried an epilator, I can promise you that your first experience with one will be painful. Remember the first time you plucked your eyebrows? It hurt! But after you've done it a few times, your body just seems to adjust to the discomfort and it never again seems as painful as that first time. Epilating works much the same way....it hurts like heck the first time you try it, but if you persevere through it you'll find the results are worth it. Epilation leaves your legs incredibly smooth, and it lasts far longer than shaving. Better still, there's no picky re-growth. You'll find that the hair that grows back is the soft, fine hair your legs once had, before you started shaving it and stimulating that tough, picky re-growth we all know and hate.<br /><br />The Braun epilator is a great little machine, and it has some advantages over the cheaper model. The light really helps me to see the tricky little hairs that used to get away. The Braun unit also utilizes a different tweezer design than the cheaper model. On the Revlon model, both sides of the \\"tweezers\\" moved, opening and closing quickly to pluck out the hairs. On the Braun, one side of the \\"tweezer\\" is stationary and made of a tacky plastic that helps to lift fine hairs....only the other side moves to create the pinching action. Because of this design, the Braun does a better job of grabbing the hairs, especially the fine ones. I had to replace my Revlon unit when the epilator went to pieces. All in all, the Braun epilator just seems to be a more sturdy machine, and in my opinion the superior design, more efficient epilation and other features make it worth the higher price.<br /><br />I love my little machine! And I can't imagine going back to shaving and those picky legs!

  1108. I did a whole lot of research before buying this, my first epilator. This is definitely the best one in this price range. There are others that cost a whole lot more, but the extras just aren't worth it. The epilator removes at least 80% of the hair the first time (usually more like 95%), even when I'm in a rush. The second time pretty much removes the rest of the 20%. While it was painful the first two or three times I used it, your body adapts and now I don't really even feel it. I've even used it for my pubic area, and it's definitely more bearable than waxing. This saves a lot of time and most importantly, there's never any stubble when the hair grows back. If you're weary of ingrown hairs or possible infections, just use rubbing alcohol on the area before and after epilating, and remember to exfoliate the area regularly. This leaves skin smoother than shaving does, takes less time than shaving or waxing, and I'd say is less painful than waxing or even shaving. (I'm taking into account my clumsiness and tendency to nick myself when I shave.) I used to shave every other day and now I can go a week or two weeks before epilating. Even when I miss a day, or even a week, there's no stubble. The product also comes with a razor head, making it a great value. The best part is that I can epilate dry and all the dark. I've even done it while studying at the computer, all without having to worry about nicking off my skin. Pros: two settings built in LED light comes with epilator head and razor head relatively painless no stubble time saver can be used dry and in the dark built well long cord for extended reach Cons: still painful potential ingrown hairs loud Overall: Great value. It does what it claims very well and even has a few bells and whistles.

  1112. I wanted to wait a while to write this review, so that I'd have an accurate assessment of my experiences. I've owned my Braun for about six months now. I bought it because I hate shaving, chemical hair removers have a horrendous smell, and even though I enjoyed the results of waxing, I didn't like the process. It was messy, awkward and time-consuming to do myself, or expensive to go to a salon. It did hurt the first few times I used it, but I got used to it quickly. I would say it's slightly less painful than waxing, and a good deal more comfortable because I can use the epilator by touch on areas I can't see terribly well. I recommend holding the skin taut where ever you can, especially sensitive areas. This gives better results and makes the process much less painful. The results were only ok at first. My skin was blotchy a red after the first few uses, and I can only describing it as itchy. I kept wanting to rub my legs. After a few weeks of consistent use, this went away completely. Each use caused less irritation, took less time and if I for some reason I can't use it for a while, I get less regrowth. After a couple months, my skin was smoother than the results I got with shaving. I've been using it about every other day and at first I did notice more ingrown hairs than I get with waxing (though not nearly so many as with shaving). I countered by ex-foliating every other day with a scrubby sponge and using the Azulene Oil that came with my Parissa wax to help sooth and moisturize my skin. This did the trick. You could probably use any moisturizer but I like the oil a lot because it's scentless. [[ASIN:B001FUUB0S Parissa Azulene Oil Aftercare, Soothing & Moisturizing 2 fl oz (60 ml)]] There are a few negatives. The light cannot be turned off/on independently of the epilator. It's a minor annoyance, but it would be nice for spot checking. It is also loud, particularly on the higher setting (which I prefer). The shaver head this comes with is useless. I tried using it for trimming as well and had better luck using an old electric razor with an attachment. I also do not recommend using this on hairs longer than a quarter inch, it's incredibly painful. All in all, I really like this epilator. It works beautifully, the results are great, they last a long time and it's easy to use. All the benefits of waxing and none of the mess!
  1113. This was the first epilator that I have bought. It works great, you may have to go over some spots more than once but it will eventually pull out all of the hair. The combination of epilator and electric shaver is a great bonus. It is a little loud, but most all epilators are and like the directions say exfoliate often afterwards otherwise you will get ingrown hairs. Overall, I would recommend this product. But, don't pay the full price for it!
  1114. I used the sugar-wax process for many years (Nads was my preference) and over time I did see a significant reduction in the number of hairs on my legs and underarms, and many of the hairs that grew back were finer. HOWEVER, I got so tired of the mess, and the entire process took way too much time. So about 3 months ago I began looking for a good epilator. A few years ago I had purchased a Braun Silk-Epil epilator for facial hair, and it worked well for about 4 years but then stopped being effective. So, naturally, when I began looking for a whole-body epilator I went to Braun's website first. I read the specs about each model, and lots of the reviews. I already knew from my waxing experience that epilating would be somewhat painful, so that did not deter me. I finally purchased the 5270 X'elle Body System Epilator -- and I am VERY pleased! It fits nicely in my hand, the light is soooo helpful for seeing the fine hairs. I do use the massaging rollers clip when epilating my underarms because that is the most tender area, and the massaging rollers do make the pain less noticeable. I also use the massaging rollers clip when epilating areas of my face. For my legs I use the Efficiency Pro Clip which covers a larger area of skin, and it works great! Oh, and cleaning the unit is a breeze! I have not used the epilator for my bikini area, I still use a razor in the shower. However, I plan to try out the shaver head for the bikini area and see if I prefer it to razor-shaving. Bottom line: If you are looking for a tool that removes hair quickly and easily (and with less pain than waxing) this is it!

  1116. I read a mountain of reviews before I took the plunge but decided to give the Braun 5270 a try and I am begrudgingly glad I did.<br /><br />First, the results are excellent, I think arguably I get better results using this little devil than I did with waxing, they are at least as good and there is no sticky mess to clean up.<br /><br />Now, for real, I don't understand why companies that sell Epilators can't stop with the false advertising, calling these devices \\"painless\\" or saying that the \\"Unique massaging action\\" makes it a painless procedure is just crazy talk. Sensitive areas like armpits, inner thighs, bikini area, the first time you epilate will feel like the worst torture that a human being could endure. I had to bite down on a soccer mouthguard to prevent myself from screaming or clenching my teeth to the point of breaking them.<br /><br />Why then, why do it? Well, as most reviewer say and I'll agree, after the first time it gets much, much better and in fact, IMO is less painful and troublesome than waxing and the ability to do it while watching tv is pretty nice. It's a convenient device and avoids the hassle and expense of a waxing appointment or a messy home waxing. And if you've had the super smooth sensation after a good wxing, you know it's just better than shaving, so you have to deal with a little pain to get that best possible look and feel.<br /><br />Both waxing and epilation provide a drastically smoother result than shaving but have a chance to leave you with more ingrown hairs. So, read the instructions and do not skip the moisturizer and definitely begin using exfoliating scrubs as directed. I have actually had fewer ingrowns or red bumps using this Epilator than I did with waxing or shaving, but I have been vigilant in exfoliation.<br /><br />I highly recommend it with the understanding that dear lord it hurts the first time, I give it four stars because they should not say it is painless or less painful or anything of the likein the advertising, and it is a little loud.oud.
  1117. I've always hated waxing because of the skin damage caused from excessive peeling. This is my first tweezer style epilator and would recommend this to ANYone tired of shaving and lacking the patience to wax. First off is to point out that, yes it will hurt like waxing. If you're not used to it that is. Mentally and physically, you adjust to it so the first time will be the worst. This is always the case with hairs that haven't been tweezed before. Just like the eyebrows, you'll eventually hardly even notice as the folicles adapt. Tips for first timers: - I highly recommend using plenty of moisturizers after your first couple times, especially if you experience retaining redness. - Keep the area clean before and after to avoid ingrown infections. I use a mini peel exfoliant every shower and lotion up afterwards. I haven't had a single ingrown and trust me when I say I have VERY sensitive skin. - Keep the heads of the epilator clean! Use rubbing alcohol and the provided brush. - Music and wine. Or a vaporizer if that's your thing.
  1118. I've only had this for a short while, so bear that in mind when reading this. I've been happy so far with the epilator part of the product. I'm accustomed to pain since i wax frequently so that hasn't been an area of concern for me. It IS a bit louder than I would have liked it, but that's not a major factor for most people. The only problems i've been having with the epilator thus far are some of the ingrown hairs i've been getting (on my legs only---my arms and underarms are fine and i haven't tried it anywhere else). My BIG area of concern however is the shaver head of the product. It is absolutely awful. It doesn't get anything at all, coarse or fine hairs it just misses them. The ones it does get are not taken anywhere near the root. Using a dull 3$ razor is more effective than this. I was disappointed since i was hoping to use it as a shaver as well (for those times when epilating just takes too long!), but that function of it is largely useless. if, however, the shaver head is just a bonus feature for you and you're really interested in the epilator, i've been happy with it so far.
  1119. I am an epilator newbie - this is my first one, so I can't compare it to others. I can only say that I am pretty happy with the purchase, even though it was pretty painful for a while. Using it is about as simple as anyone could ask, and the product comes with several ways to remove the hair, including a decent shaver and different heads to reduce pain, which are moderately effective. Let's face it: you're pulling hairs out at the roots. There is no painless way to do this, but if you do it immediately after a hot bath or shower, it's a bit easier, and after a while, if you use it consistently, the hair does come in a bit thinner and sparser. I have very pale skin and very dark hair, so shaving is pointless for summer. I hated waxing because of the expense and the pain of the hot wax plus the yanking and tweezing, and the need to plan ahead, plus I got in-grown hairs pretty often. With the epilator, I can remove hair when I want to, and the cost has already been easily made up, for how many times I would have had to get waxed at a salon for $25 a pop. I still get hairs that grow under the skin, but they are not as deep under as with waxing, for some reason, so they don't cause painful bumps, and I can get them out easily. Pros: convenient, good time and money saver, attachments that reduce pain, still better than hot wax Cons: painful to some extent, some broken hairs with the attachments (this is reduced by a lot if you can take the attachments off. This took many months for me to be able to do.)
